original_title: US reassures depositors as bad money trigger bank failures
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – The US Treasury, the Fed and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation released a joint statement as bank failures began after several years of bad money which triggered high inflation and mal-investments.

“Today we are taking decisive actions to protect the U.S. economy by strengthening public confidence in our banking system,” Secretary of the Treasury Janet L. Yellen, Fed  Chief Jerome H. Powell, and FDIC Chairman Martin J. Gruenberg said in a joint statement.

“This step will ensure that the U.S. banking system continues to perform its vital roles of protecting deposits and providing access to credit to households and businesses in a manner that promotes strong and sustainable economic growth.”
At the same time FDIC also took over Signature Bank, based in New York and transferred its assets to a new entity.

The statement came as Silicon Valley Bank, which had a large volumes of Treasury Securities made mark-to-market losses and was unable to pay depositors as interest rates rose suddenly after several years of excessive money printing by the Fed.

The failures come as Fed printed money for real economy reasons or stimulus, going against the basic principles of 200 years of classical economics.

Especially during the Covid crisis, any assistance which should have been provided by the Treasury borrowings a slightly higher interest rate, was backed up by printed money, which produced rates lower than it would have otherwise been.
Banks are now being hit on their gilt portfolios as interest rates go back up.
Excess money also triggered other mal-investment including in stocks and cryptocurrencies. Two banks which were shut earlier this month have links to crypto.
The Fed said separately that it was opening a new funding line for troubled banks, supposedly the original reason for creating the Fed.
The funding will come at par value and no hair cut or mark-to-market values, which hit Silicon Valley Bank and depleted its capital.
“This action will bolster the capacity of the banking system to safeguard deposits and ensure the ongoing provision of money and credit to the economy,” the Fed said in a statement.
“The Federal Reserve is prepared to address any liquidity pressures that may arise.

“The additional funding will be made available through the creation of a new Bank Term Funding Program (BTFP), offering loans of up to one year in length to banks, savings associations, credit unions, and other eligible depository institutions pledging U.S. Treasuries, agency debt and mortgage-backed securities, and other qualifying assets as collateral.

Early theoreticians including Walter Bagehot had advocated that central bank money should only be used to help banks which had solvent, but could not meet a deposit run due to the inability to liquidate assets.
The Fed was created to help banks which faced occasional runs, in 1916 ending a free banking era following the so-called Panic of 1907. The panic was averted by liquidity from JP Morgan.

According to reports, JP Morgan had bought very little long bonds in the Covid bubble, as interest rates were considered too low and had taken in lower levels of deposits that came from pandemic checques and reduced consumption.
The Fed soon started to operate a policy rate, against its gold peg, triggering roaring 20s bubble and the Great Depression as brakes were hit like now.
The Feds gold peg was then busted to 35 dollars ounce from 20 during the Great Depression by so-called New Dealers.

Fed then continued to operate a policy rate after World War II and destroyed the 200 year gold standard in 1971-72 sending gold prices above 86 dollars, triggering the Great Inflation period with an un-anchored floating rate.
Floating rates were controlled by Fed Chief Paul Volcker from 1980 onwards, followed by Alan Greenspan.

In 2001, the Fed Chief Greenspan, supposedly misled by Bernanke, provided bad money in an 8-year cycle in the process of generating positive inflation, ending the 20 year Great Moderation and triggered another massive bank run and the Great Recession.

The latest bank failures, are in part triggered due to bond bought at low prices during the Covid liquidity injections.

Central banks have enormous power and usually operate outside of parliamentary oversight using a principle of central bank independence, targeting output and inflating money supply and triggering banking crises.
In pegged arrangements, central banks trigger currency crises and external defaults in the process of targeting output.
Washington, DC — The following statement was released by Secretary of the Treasury Janet L. Yellen, Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome H. Powell, and FDIC Chairman Martin J. Gruenberg:

Today we are taking decisive actions to protect the U.S. economy by strengthening public confidence in our banking system. This step will ensure that the U.S. banking system continues to perform its vital roles of protecting deposits and providing access to credit to households and businesses in a manner that promotes strong and sustainable economic growth.

After receiving a recommendation from the boards of the FDIC and the Federal Reserve, and consulting with the President, Secretary Yellen approved actions enabling the FDIC to complete its resolution of Silicon Valley Bank, Santa Clara, California, in a manner that fully protects all depositors. Depositors will have access to all of their money starting Monday, March 13. No losses associated with the resolution of Silicon Valley Bank will be borne by the taxpayer.

We are also announcing a similar systemic risk exception for Signature Bank, New York, New York, which was closed today by its state chartering authority. All depositors of this institution will be made whole. As with the resolution of Silicon Valley Bank, no losses will be borne by the taxpayer.

Shareholders and certain unsecured debtholders will not be protected. Senior management has also been removed. Any losses to the Deposit Insurance Fund to support uninsured depositors will be recovered by a special assessment on banks, as required by law.

Finally, the Federal Reserve Board on Sunday announced it will make available additional funding to eligible depository institutions to help assure banks have the ability to meet the needs of all their depositors.

The U.S. banking system remains resilient and on a solid foundation, in large part due to reforms that were made after the financial crisis that ensured better safeguards for the banking industry. Those reforms combined with today’s actions demonstrate our commitment to take the necessary steps to ensure that depositors’ savings remain safe. (Colombo/Mar13/2022)
